column1: ### 5KW Solar Integrated Solar Power System with 5kWh Lithium Power Battery Backup and 2200w of Solar Panels
**Total Cost: From R99.000 –  R132000+ depending on inverter, solar panels and battery brand.**

This comprehensive package includes a robust solar-integrated backup power system, ideal for small to medium-sized households seeking a reliable power solution and the opportunity to reduce their monthly utility costs.
- The system comes equipped with **four 550-watt solar panels,** enabling the generation of your own power. It ensures consistent power availability in sunny conditions.

- Designed to strike an optimal balance between performance and affordability, this system is an excellent choice for households aiming for both a dependable backup power source and solar energy benefits.
- The system’s **5 Kilowatt-hour backup power capacity** can deliver over **10 hours of continuous power at a 400-watt draw.**
- The **solar panels are capable of producing approximately 2200 watts** at peak sunlight conditions.
- Over 5 Kilowatt hours of high-grade Lithium Iron Phosphate batteries.
- Professional wiring of the inverter to essential circuits on your distribution board, inclusive of changeover switches and breakers.
- Installation of four 550+ watt solar panels with a 20+ year warranty, complete with all necessary wiring and breakers.
- A compliance certificate is included, subject to the existing electrical compliance of the premises (\*See additional note).
**This system is a full-service solution, offering both energy independence and peace of mind with its seamless integration and reliable backup power capabilities.**
### 8KW Solar Integrated Solar Power System with 14kWh Lithium Power Battery Backup and 4400w of Solar Panels
**Total Price: R154.000 –  R209000 depending on the inverter, solar panels and battery brand.**

This enhanced system offers a significant upgrade with a more powerful inverter and an increased number of solar panels, making it an ideal choice for medium to larger households. It’s designed for those who seek extensive backup power capabilities and significant reductions in monthly electricity costs.
- The expanded capacity makes it possible to manage most household loads efficiently, ensuring abundant backup power and substantial savings on electricity bills.
- The investment in this upgraded system is well worth the substantial benefits and savings it offers.
- The system’s **14 Kilowatt-hour backup power capacity** can deliver more than **35 hours of continuous power at a 400-watt draw.**
- Equipped with eight high-efficiency **solar panels, the system can generate over 4400 watts** in peak sunlight conditions.
- A superior quality hybrid smart inverter, 8kw, 48-volt.
- 10 Kilowatt hours of top-tier Lithium Iron Phosphate batteries.
- Professional wiring of the inverter to key circuits on your distribution board, complete with changeover switches and breakers.
- Installation of eight 550+ watt solar panels, backed by a 20+ year warranty, inclusive of all necessary wiring and breakers.
- A compliance certificate, contingent on the existing electrical compliance of your property (\*See additional note).
This system is not only a powerful energy solution but also an investment in long-term cost savings and energy efficiency for larger households.
### 12KW 3 Phase Solar Integrated Solar Power System with 20kWh Lithium Power Battery Backup and 8800w of Solar Panels
**Total Price: R275000 –  R385000 depending on the inverter, solar panels and battery brand.**

This advanced solar power system features a 12 Kilowatt 3-phase inverter, a significant 20 Kilowatt-hour battery capacity, and 14 high-wattage solar panels. It’s an exceptional choice for medium households aiming for off-grid living, and larger households seeking substantial independence from the grid.
- The system’s robust design and substantial power output make it ideal for achieving nearly complete energy independence.
- The increased number of solar panels and larger battery capacity enhance the system’s efficiency and reliability.
- The system’s **20 Kilowatt-hour backup power** can provide over **50 hours of continuous power at a 400-watt draw.**
- The 16 premium **solar panels are capable of generating approximately 8,000 watts** at peak sunlight.
- Equipped with 20 Kilowatt hours of top-grade Lithium Iron Phosphate batteries.
- Professional wiring of the inverter to essential circuits on your distribution board, complete with changeover switches and breakers.
- Roof installation of 16 high-quality 550+ watt solar panels, each with a 20+ year guarantee, including all necessary wiring and breakers.
- Comprehensive electrical installation services are part of the package.
- A compliance certificate is provided, subject to the existing electrical compliance of the installation site (\*See additional note).
This comprehensive solar power system is tailored for households seeking a high-capacity, reliable solar solution to significantly reduce or eliminate dependence on traditional power sources.
## Factors Influencing the Solar Panel Prices and Solar PV Prices

When considering the installation of a solar power system, it’s important to understand the various factors that can influence the overall cost. These factors ensure that each solar installation is unique to the homeowner’s needs and property specifics. Here are some key aspects that affect the pricing:

- **System Size and Capacity:** The size of the solar system, typically measured in kilowatts (kW), is one of the primary determinants of cost. Larger systems with higher capacity are more expensive due to the increased number of solar panels and additional hardware required.

- **Type and Quality of Solar Panels:** There are different types of solar panels (like monocrystalline, polycrystalline, and thin-film), each with varying efficiency and costs. Higher-efficiency panels are usually more expensive but can be more cost-effective in the long run.

- **Inverter Type:** The inverter is a critical component that converts solar energy into usable electricity. The type (string inverters, microinverters, or hybrid inverters) and quality of the inverter can significantly impact the cost.

- **Battery Storage:** Adding a battery storage system allows for the storage of excess solar energy, which can be used when the sun isn’t shining. The inclusion of a battery system increases the initial investment but can offer greater energy independence and savings.

- **Installation Complexity:** The complexity of the installation process can vary based on the property. Factors like roof type, angle, and accessibility, as well as any special installation requirements, can affect the overall cost.

- **Location and Climate:** Geographic location influences the amount of sunlight available for solar energy production. Additionally, local climate conditions can affect the type of equipment needed and the installation process.

- **Government Incentives and Rebates:** The South African National Treasury has set forth guidelines for accessing the ZAR4 billion rebate program for residential solar PV systems, initiated in February. Homeowners can receive a 25% rebate on solar panel costs, capped at ZAR16500. In the 2023/24 filing season, PAYE taxpayers can claim this rebate, and provisional taxpayers can apply it against their provisional and final payments. Eligibility requires a VAT invoice detailing the solar panel costs and proof of payment. Furthermore, for systems purchased between March 1, 2023, and February 29, 2026, a compliance certificate with the 2009 Electrical Installation Regulations is mandatory. The rebate covers solar panels in new or existing systems with at least 275 W output, excluding portable panels.

- **Labor Costs:** The cost of professional installation varies by region and the expertise of the installers. Choosing certified and experienced installers ensures system efficiency and safety, which might come at a higher cost.
- **Maintenance and Additional Features:** Long-term maintenance costs and additional features like monitoring systems also contribute to the overall expense of a solar power system.
- **Electrical Upgrades:** Sometimes, existing electrical systems may need upgrades to accommodate the new solar system, adding to the installation cost.
Save money on your new Solar Installation by talking to one of our vetted [Solar Companies](https://www.localpros.co.za/solar-installers/) in your area.
## How to Save Money on Your Solar PV Installations

Investing in a solar installation can be financially significant, but there are several strategies to make it more affordable and maximize your investment. Here are some tips to save money on your solar panel installations:

- **Research Government Incentives and Rebates:** The South African National Treasury has outlined guidelines to access the ZAR4 billion rebate program for residential solar PV systems, launched in February. Homeowners can claim a rebate equal to 25% of their solar panel costs, up to ZAR16500. For the 2023/24 filing season, PAYE taxpayers can claim this rebate, while provisional taxpayers can offset it against their provisional and final payments. To be eligible, homeowners must provide a VAT invoice that separately details the cost of the solar PV panels and proof of payment. For systems purchased between March 1, 2023, and February 29, 2026, a compliance certificate with the 2009 Electrical Installation Regulations is required. The rebate is applicable to solar panels in both new and existing systems, with a minimum output of 275 W, but excludes portable panels.

- **Choose the Right System Size:** Opt for a solar system size that matches your energy needs. Over-sizing can lead to unnecessary expenses, while under-sizing may not provide the desired energy savings.
- **Compare Quotes from Multiple Providers:** Get quotations from several solar installers. Comparing prices and services can help you find the best deal and avoid overpaying.
- **Consider Panel Type and Efficiency:** While higher-efficiency panels are more expensive, they can produce more energy in less space. Assess if the long-term savings justify the initial cost.
- **Look for Financing Options:** Explore financing options like solar loans or leases, which can spread the cost over time, making the initial investment more manageable.
- **Invest in Quality Equipment:** Choosing high-quality solar panels and components can be cost-effective in the long run due to their durability and efficiency.

- **DIY Some Aspects of the Installation:** If you have the necessary skills, you can save on labor costs by doing some installation work yourself. However, professional assistance is crucial for electrical connections and complex installations.
- **Plan for Long-Term Performance:** Ensure regular maintenance to keep your solar system running efficiently. This can prevent costly repairs and maintain optimal energy production.

- **Utilize Energy Efficiently:** Adopt energy-efficient practices in your home or business to reduce overall energy consumption. This means a smaller solar system can meet your energy needs, lowering costs.
- **Monitor Energy Usage:** Use monitoring systems to track energy production and consumption. This data can help you adjust usage patterns to maximize solar benefits.

By carefully planning and researching, you can find ways to reduce the cost of your solar installation while enjoying the benefits of renewable energy. Talk to a [Solar Installer Near You](https://www.localpros.co.za/solar-installers/) they can help you make the right choice.
## Lower the Price of Your Solar PV Installation By Choosing the Right Solar PV System Base On Your Monthly Demand
In addition to the previous guidelines for choosing the right solar system size, here are specific system recommendations for households with monthly consumptions of 300, 500, 800, and 1000 kWh
- **Solar Panel Wattage:** With **550W panels, around 4 panels** would now suffice, totaling approximately 2200 watts.
- **Battery Size:** Approximately **6-8 kWh** for adequate daily usage storage and backup.
- **Inverter Size: 5 kW**(or **6-7 kW for better performance**).
- **Solar Panel Wattage:** About **7 panels,** giving a total of around **3850 watts.**
- **Battery Size: 10-12 kWh** to adequately cover daily energy needs and ensure backup power.
- I **nverter Size: 8 kW** for optimal handling of energy production.
- Solar Panel Wattage: Roughly **11 panels** would be needed, resulting in a **total of around 6050 watts.**
- **Battery Size:** Around **16-20 kWh** is recommended for sufficient storage and backup.
- **Inverter Size:** **A 10 kW** inverter would be most suitable.
- **Solar Panel Wattage:** Around **13-14 panels,** amounting to approximately **7150 – 7700 watts.**
- **Battery Size:** Consider a **20-24 kWh** battery to meet daily energy requirements and provide backup.

- **These revised panel numbers are based on South Africa’s higher-than-average solar irradiance** but are still approximate. The **actual number may vary depending on specific site conditions and energy usage patterns.**
- **Regular evaluation and maintenance of the solar system can further optimize its performance** in such a sunny environment.
- It’s **advisable** to consult with local [solar energy experts](https://www.localpros.co.za/solar-installers/) for precise sizing and installation tailored to your particular needs and location.

How much will you spend on a home solar system?
# How much does a home solar system cost?
Thinking of going solar? The upfront cost can be scary, but the benefits are clear.

Finding the right home solar solution can be a time-consuming and confusing exercise. Considering[the cost involved,](https://personal.nedbank.co.za/learn/blog/affordable-solar-steps-to-get-off-the-grid.html ""See how to get off the grid in affordable steps"")this is not something you want to get wrong. If the system’s too small, it won’t power your home when needed, and if it’s too big you’re spending too much to produce more electricity than you can use.

We’ve compared [the general costs](https://personal.nedbank.co.za/learn/blog/hidden-costs-of-going-solar.html ""Don't overlook the hidden costs of going solar"")of 3 different options you can use to generate your own power at home and reduce your reliance on the national grid – or end it completely.

For the purpose of this exercise, we’re going to compare the cost of 5kW solar photovoltaic systems used as a grid-tied, hybrid or fully off-grid installation. A system of this size should be enough for a household that pays around R1,400 for electricity every month, using roughly 960kWh.

If you have a smaller home and [use less electricity,](https://personal.nedbank.co.za/learn/blog/going-off-grid-lifestyle-changes.html ""Learn how some changes can help you use less electricity"")your costs would be a little lower. If you have a larger home, you’re going to need a bigger budget.

The prices used in these examples have been taken from a reputable supplier that offers home solar kits, including all the components, brackets and connectors you’ll need to install a solar system. Costs exclude installation, electrical certificate of compliance and any other service charges.
## **The cost of a grid-tied solar system**

A grid-tied system is one that produces energy whenever you have enough sunlight, but also draws power from the grid when your system isn’t generating enough electricity. This is the cheapest option because it excludes the most expensive component in any solar power system – the batteries. For this installation, 6 solar panels and an inverter (to convert the direct current from the panels into the alternating current used in your home) should be enough to produce the power you need during the day.

In our example, this solution should cost you between R55,000 and R60,000, but you will be using less grid electricity during the day, so the cost will be offset to an extent by savings on your electricity bill.

The advantage of a hybrid system is that it can generate and store electricity most of the time and draw power from the electricity grid only when needed. A hybrid system adds battery storage between the solar panels and your inverter.
#### Generating twice as much power as you consume is a wide safety margin for your off-grid system

But as mentioned, the price increases sharply when you add batteries to the system. For a hybrid system as described, you might want to install 2 batteries to have enough power stored when long periods of cloudy weather cause your system to produce less electricity than usual.
Our chosen hybrid solution with 8 solar panels and 2 batteries will cost you between R115,000 and R120,000.
## **The cost of an off-grid solar system**

Being free of the electricity grid and constant power outages comes at a cost. Yes, you have your own power source, but you’re also totally reliant on it working as it should. If it doesn’t, you'll be left without any electricity and no easy access to an alternative.

That’s why a totally off-grid system needs more solar panels to feed the much bigger bank of batteries to ensure you have enough electricity to run everything in your home and enough stored to keep everything running until the batteries can be recharged by solar power alone.

For this scenario, we considered using as many as 5 batteries, giving you storage capacity of about 18kWh, and needing 8 solar panels to recharge your batteries fully every day. This is not a very big margin of safety, so we also looked at a 9-battery solution that needs 14 solar panels but can store up to 33kWh, double your daily average.
Generating twice as much power as you consume is a wide safety margin for your off-grid system, but it comes at a cost – close to R250,000, to be exact.
## **Counting the cost of going off the grid**

At first glance, these numbers might seem [a little scary.](https://personal.nedbank.co.za/learn/blog/insure-your-home-solar-energy-system.html ""Learn how to insure your solar-power system"") It’s a big investment and a big decision to choose a system and how you’re going to finance it. But if you break down the numbers, you could well justify such a big outlay of money.

We offer Nedbank clients [specialised home solar financing options](https://personal.nedbank.co.za/borrow/solar-finance.html ""See your solar finance options with Nedbank"") from approved service providers as a cost-effective way to reap the benefits of a home solar system.

Please note that all costs and financing options quoted in this blog were correct at the time of publication, but are subject to change without notice. Although we update the blogs regularly to keep the information up to date, clients are advised to check current costs and finance options with service providers before making any commitment to solar installation.",,"Solar power to provide some or all of your electricity can cost from R55,000 to R250,000 – but it’s affordable in stages.",,,https://personal.nedbank.co.za/content/dam/nedbank/logos/favicon.ico

Rising silver prices intensify pressure across solar value chain as solar panel prices edge higher - Green Building Africa,https://www.greenbuildingafrica.co.za/rising-silver-prices-intensify-pressure-across-solar-value-chain-as-solar-panel-prices-edge-higher/,"[![PV Transact](https://www.greenbuildingafrica.co.za/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/pvt_728x90.png)](https://www.pvtransact.co.za/)
- **Higher silver and polysilicon prices are pushing up costs for cells and modules with distributed generation projects seeing price increases first.**
- **Wafer and cell prices in China are stabilising at higher levels while transaction volumes remain subdued.**
- **Solar panel (module) makers are lifting quotes for 2026 deliveries in both China and international markets amid cautious demand outlook.**

Rising silver prices are adding fresh cost pressure across the global solar photovoltaic supply chain, reinforcing expectations of higher prices for cells and modules, according to the latest analysis from **[InfoLink Consulting.](https://www.infolink-group.com/)**

Price increase signals have become more pronounced in recent weeks, with transactions in the distributed generation segment moving up ahead of large scale utility projects. The rapid rise in silver prices has significantly increased production costs at cell level, making it more difficult for manufacturers to absorb upstream increases.

Polysilicon prices in China continue to edge higher, with new orders transacted mainly through limited strategic or contractual arrangements. Recent deals have been concluded at around RMB 60 to 65 per kilogram, while overall new quotations are expected to settle at RMB 63 to 65 per kilogram, led by tier one suppliers.

Most trading volumes remain linked to earlier contracts, although transaction prices are showing a clear upward bias. Outside China, polysilicon prices remain firm, with spot prices in the United States rising as buyers hedge against potential policy risks. Market sentiment remains cautious due to rising inventories and seasonally weak demand, with production discipline in the first quarter expected to play a key role in stabilising prices.
**Wafer and cell markets show price resilience**

Wafer prices in China remained largely stable week on week, although actual transaction levels suggest a gradual upward movement. Improved acceptance of current wafer prices by cell manufacturers is helping to support the market, particularly for the 183N format, which is gaining production share.

Cell prices in China increased again this week, with average prices across mainstream N type formats reaching RMB 0.39 per watt. Leading manufacturers have begun quoting above RMB 0.40 per watt following the surge in silver prices, while some have suspended deliveries due to mounting cost pressures. As a result, transaction volumes have declined sharply and production cuts are expected to extend into February.
In export markets, both P type and N type cell prices have also moved higher, especially for products using non China polysilicon and shipped from Southeast Asia to the United States.

Module manufacturers in China have started to raise quotes in response to higher upstream costs and industry self regulation measures. Distributed generation projects are again leading price increases, while utility scale projects are adjusting more gradually.

Average TOPCon module prices in China have risen to around RMB 0.70 per watt, supported by a higher share of distributed projects. HJT module prices have also been revised upward, with higher power ratings commanding a premium.

In non China markets, module prices remain broadly stable for near term deliveries, but suppliers are increasing quotes for 2026 orders. Europe has seen modest upward adjustments linked to silver costs, while prices in Asia Pacific, the Middle East and Latin America remain competitive. In the United States, pricing continues to diverge widely depending on supply routes and compliance requirements.

Looking ahead, InfoLink Consulting notes that demand is likely to remain soft in the first quarter of 2026 due to seasonal factors and higher prices. While cost pressures are expected to persist, cautious procurement sentiment and limited order visibility suggest that further price increases may face resistance in the near term.
